ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gain a better understanding of the procedure of paper writing and grant writing
Basic information on how to give a talk, how to write a paper, how to apply to grants.
I learned a bit about the grad school process and writing through this course.
the course made me think about writing styles and strategies, as well as presentation techniques.
During this course the speakers gave us suggestions on how to write papers and grants. Additionally, they gave us advice on how to select a journal to submit our work in.
Where to look, and who to find for resources needed during grant and research paper submission.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Almost all of the lectures were not very useful, and I could have learned the material if they had simply printed out their slides and gave them to us to read. The only lecture that I thought was really useful was Prof. Greco's lecture on how to give a scientific presentation. I thought this class was a pretty big waste of time, but I did think that the instructors were trying hard to make the class interesting. I just thought that first year grad students were not the correct audience for many of the lectures. For example, I thought that the four-lecture series on how to write a manuscript was more geared towards students from high school or early undergraduates who had never written scientifically before. There were many quick group writing assignments, which we would then peer edit. This setup was not very useful because feedback on an assignment that you wrote with three other people in five minutes cannot really be applied to improve your own writing. I also wanted the examples to be actual examples from biological writing, since that is the type of writing that is relevant to all of our interests and careers.
Too much time wasted in some really boring topics
weakness - lectures on how to write a paper were a little drawn out even though the lecturer was good; wasn't very applicable to our current position in grad school

The instructors are great. They are knowledgeable, and they have good presentation skills to make the class interesting. Sometimes the pace is slow (such as the four paper writing classes). Sometimes we hear a lot of information that we already know (such as the how to do presentation class), and other times we are given information that we will not use until years later (such as the paper writing class)

First classes were very interesting and engaging. The classes related to paper writing were too many. I don't think we need that much information on those topics right now and will probably have to learn it again on the future anyways. I don't think the mock rotation talks were that useful because we still practice with our labs and friends, and get same or better feedback.
I think it would have been useful to write a grant application, even a practice one, during this course.

The writing sessions were much too long- the useful info was always in the first half hour, and the examples were excessive. Dr. Greco's and Dr. Colon-Ramos' lectures were really inspiring and useful.
The classes on how to make a presentation and the mock presentations were very helpful.
Many of the topics/lectures provided no additional knowledge, and were not useful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not recommend this course to another student, but we have to take it for our program. I also thought that it was kind of ridiculous that we were not allowed to miss more than one class even for medical reasons.
Yes, but only with a select course topics.
